listWit.witness: Madras, Government Oriental manuscripts Library, no. 3378. Ma is a Devanāgarī transcript of an original palmleaf MS written in the Malayāḷaṃ script. It consists of two parts of which the pages have been numbered separately: 1-11 and 1-225. The main, second, part contains the Gāthās from 11 up to and including 474 of the Third South-Indian recension. The text is accompanied by the Sanskrit commentary of Mādhavayajvamiśra. ... In Roman characters the following particulars have been added: Transcribed in 1920-21 from a MS of Narayanan Namburipad of Kutalur Mana, Nareri, Tritala, Malabar Dt. Compared with the original MS. M. A. J., 19-4-1921.

div.p: Bow before the moon-face of Gaurī which by her anger at Paśupati has become the counterpart of the morning sky; it looks like the cupped hands filled with Saṃdhyā-water, holding a (red) Arghya-lotus.

div.p: Those who do not know how to read and listen to (this) nectarlike Kāvya in Prākrit, but are solely concerned with scholarly works (in Sanskrit) on love, how can they not feel ashamed?

lg.l: ṇohaliamṇohaliyaṃdohaliaṃṇoaliaṃ appaṇoayyaṇo kiṃ ṇa maggase maggase kuravaassakuruvaassa
eaṃā khukhatuvukkhuvvia kkhu tuha hasaï suhaahasaï tuha sahaatuha suhaa hasaïsuhaa hasaï tuha valiamuhaviliyamuhavaliāṇaṇavaliāṇapaṃkaaṃpaṃkaja jāā.

div.p: Why don’t you look for a ‘yield of new fruits’ for yourself instead of looking for a ‘young woman’ for the kurabaka-tree? Thus, you know, handsome man, your wife is laughing, her lotus-face turned aside.

eāṇaeāṇaṃ vālabālacālavāluṃkibālukkivālukvivālukkivalukkivālukivālukkitaṃtubhuṃtukuḍilāṇakuḍilāṇaṃ pemmāṇapemmāṇaṃPāda a is quoted in Hem.2.195 (erisi, v.l. erise, ccia)..

div.p: Friend, stop crying with your moon-face turned aside: this is the course of these affectionate feelings which ‘curl’ (indiscriminately around everyone who is available) like the tendrils of the young cucumber-plant.

div.head: 11 (12 Ma, 13 Tp; 10 Bh, 11 R; K, ψ, B, γ, P, G, ξ; 590 T; 322 S). Missing in W.

lg.l: pāavaḍiassapāapaḍiassa païṇo paṭṭhiṃ puttepaṭṭhiṃ païṇo puttepaïṇo puṭṭhiṃ puttepaïṇo puṭhṭhiṃ puttepaïṇo putte paṭṭhiṃ samāruhaṃtammiruhaṃtamruhaṃtaṃmmi

div.p: When their son climbed on her husband's back who had fallen at her feet, the wife could not help laughing, even though she was tormented by a fierce anger.

div.p: I must say, she knows what looking is! Passion for a man who is one's equal is right (but not for a man like you). Let her die! I will not tell you (what she asked me to tell you). Even such a dreadful thing as death is to be welcomed by her (in this situation).
